reviewText:
My overall opinion: A pretty good game, it won't be liked by some people but I gotta say the story and the choices you make/say really did feel like a real choice and the ending wasn't set in stone and there are quite a few ways your journey may end earlier or differently

(WARNING! THERE ARE SOME HINTED SPOILERS!)

(This Is Just My Own Personal Opinion And How I Felt The Game Was To Me And You Might Feel Different To My Point Of View So Please Be Nice Kay? =)

It wasn't a game where you can just get the best ending by just rushing to the end and picking the right dialog, it was focused on choices and life decisions that can cause your own story to end suddenly by taking the wrong turn in life.

There are some flaws that I felt made the game feel annoying at some points like the boxing minigame or earning enough income in a short time open up another dialog option later in the story but without knowing all this beforehand you'll be left with just one thing, your own personal choice. (and this is without being a cheat and reading a how-to guide!)

The epilogue felt open ended and you cannot revisit the previous town/cities to check up on how they are all doing and your main love interest (if you choose to persue it) simply locks him/herself in a room and you end up having a limit set of options you could do.

I truely wished there was abit more to the story in the epilogue, I kinda felt cheated after going through everything just to have my main love interest lock him/herself in so I cannot see or talk to him/her and having it end just like that because I felt there could be abit more story between the main character and the love interest rather than relying mostly on flashback/dreams and maybe having them go together to revisit the town/cities the main character have gone to and see where it goes from there.

Heres hoping for dlc or a sequel! but I doubt they'd do that, happens too often~ =P

Anyways, this is a good game in which I will play again to see what else it has to offer and the main theme of the game is probably the choice in life and maybe something else =P , I hope you enjoy it if you do buy the game, its total recommended game to get!

reviewText:
If I could have given this game a neutral rating I would have, but since I have to pick one I’ve gone with recommending it.

ASM certainly got me hooked at the start – the freedom of character choice was good, and it seemed like there was a lot to do. From Day 1, there are quite a few options available to you, and many choices you can make. The game claims to run on a system where every small choice affects you, but in the end that doesn’t really happen.

The games plot is linear – no matter which decisions you make, you always end up travelling between certain places to make your way towards your ex’s wedding, although there are a few options on how to do that dictated by what your do in the places you visit. A lot of short side missions never really do anything – the phrase “You’re a good friend” appears several times throughout the story, but these characters never really do anything else afterwards. One of the side missions even seems like it’s going to reappear near the end (when it turns out a big event happening at the same time as the wedding is one you can win a pass to for someone) but that doesn’t go anywhere, the kid you help out is completely missing from the last arc. No matter your actions, you’ll end up in the final situation where all that happens is you might have locked yourself out of the endings.

Speaking of the endings… my main gripe with this game is that they’re unsatisfying. Endings don’t necessarily need to be happy, but all of the outcomes for ASM leave a sour taste in one’s mouth. To start off with, the stamina system (which exists solely to keep you spending money on food or fishing) means that if you go to sleep when it’s too low, game over. It’s far too abrupt. Obviously it doesn’t need to be dramatic, but a little cutscene of what happens during the night would help rather than the screen flashing “YOU DIED IN YOUR SLEEP” and taking you back to the title screen. I presume something similar happens if you manage to waste enough time to miss the wedding – although there may be some event that forces you to get there anyway. As for the main endings, some of them flat out don’t work – such as you becoming a millionaire but inexplicably becoming a hobo, and others just see that characters don’t work together. Even the ‘perfect’ ending sees your love hint at being discontent with the situation, before leaving you in a pointless epilogue which seems to exist just so you can play the video games freely or try and hit up a high score in time spent in the shower, which could have been accomplished by adding an extra option to the title screen upon completion.
The moral of the game seems to be that you either have to screw people over or be a successful gambler to make any money. I disagree with it but I understand why the developers have done it.

However, for all its flaws, I did enjoy the game (sans the ending.) Of the 10 or so hours I put into it, I enjoyed most of them – the story is nothing spectacular, but it’s enjoyable. The graphics aren’t the best and the music choice is all over the place but I still liked playing it (even if most of the time was spent save scumming on scratch cards, races and casinos.) The developers insert themselves from time to time and there are other brief moments of humour which certainly help with the experience.

All in all, ASM claims that it presents a story which is heavily decided by the choices you make. As you’d expect, this isn’t the case because that would be a development nightmare. Despite that, the game is mostly enjoyable despite having a bitter aftertaste due to the unsatisfying endings. While I don’t think Vagabond Dog have hit it off with this game, it looks like there is a lot of potential so I’ll probably keep an eye out to see what else they’ve got in store in the future.

reviewText: Always Sometimes Monsters is a game where you live the life of a broken adult, trying to reclaim their life but face many decisions that a normal human being would most likely never face. This is the story of your character, whom ever it may be, facing many everyday problems, from money to love. It is an amazing game that always managed to throw my emotions around and made me feel for the character. The one thing I would complain about this game is how the game handles money. Every main quest" has some cash output for you to progress
date: but these "main quests" do not give enough money. After you are done with these "main quests"
recommended: you are stuck to do an odd job at a employment agency to get the remaining cash to progress and these jobs are very tedious and boring
hoursPlayed: unlike the rest of the game. I would recommend this game to anyone willing to dish out 10 dollars and ~7-8 of their life for an amazing story and never ending music that WILL get stuck in your head."

reviewText: You are a writer struggling to make ends meet and life keeps screwing you over. You get kicked out of your apartment, you have to work menial jobs to make barely enough to feed yourself, and your significant other left you. You receive their wedding invitation in the mail and decide to make your way across the country to get there in time, but what happens along the way is really up to you. It's a game about choice, consequences, and asking the question of what matters and what you decide to live for. It does a wonderful job and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
I'm going to do a Pros / Cons list to make things easy and quick for you

Pros:
+Lets you pick your own path through the game
+You can make your own relationships with characters, and not ones a game would want you to have
+You don't automatically have all the money in the world, you have to earn it
+You can be a good guy, or a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

Cons:
-Far too much talking to keep it entertaining
-Lots of walking around
-Tiny screen, and fullscreen is just a black box around the window
-Controls are obnoxious (No mouse controls!)
-Conversations become very tedious. I began to not care what people were saying
-Annoying pauses in gameplay so that emotes can pop up above characters
-A variation of about 2-3 emotes
-Character pictures are very cheesy
-No character customization, I was really hoping for some
-Picking your sexual preference is very confusing at the beginning. Accidentally became a lesbian
-Game runs out of entertaining tasks very quickly
-I found myself sleeping over and over again to try see if I could start a mission

There are many more cons, but I feel I don't need to list all of the minor ones.
Overall, my rating is 4.5/10

Spend your money on something else, unless this game is on sale for $0.99

reviewText: Always Sometimes Monsters is a game i would recomend. With witty dialouge, questions that define you morales, and all those dark points in the game. Well writen, it provides quite the experiance. However, my problem with the game isn't a sucky ending, or a simple point of insult, much rather my proble lies in the game itself... literaly.\n\nThere I am, about to make an important choise, or just walking down the hallway, or just transitioning from place to place, then all of a sudden my screen goes black. The audio is still running! I can still access the windows screen! Nothing is frozen except for the game. Even worse, I have to start all over again! You see, it effected all my saves, and packing boxes over and over again is not fun. I tried to uninstall it then reinstall, didn't work. I went through the games files and it didn't work. Until this bug is fixed, I'm afraid it puts a handicap on the amount of enjoyment you can have. I still recommend it though, and I realise that not everyone will have this bug, but i hope that such a bug is fixed soon.

reviewText: A brutal emotional ride that takes your perspective of what's right and wrong to task and is as close to a proper 'road movie' as a video game will ever get, Always Sometimes Monsters does stumble with some clunky bedroom-philosophy writing, tired 8-bit aesthetics and (intentionally?) tedious gameplay sections, but the bleak, gut-punch of a story lifts it way beyond the medium's standard and builds to a satisfying, heartbreaking climax.

reviewText: My girl left me, my publisher fired me, I'm broke, AND THE PROM IS TOMORROW!\n\nOn a more serious note, this is a great game that got me geniunely involved with the characters. Most games make you abundently clear that the characters are just that- characters. But in Always Sometimes monsters, I really felt like they were real people, with real consequences for my actions. This isn't a game for everyone, but for someone who likes adventures, a smidge of romance, and grey-and-grey moral choices that could end in disaster or in triumph, this is a shining example of what an RPG should look like. My only qualm was that it wasn't long enough.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of negative comments/reviews which did surprise me but at the same time I get why.

This game is not for everyone. It's not some hardcore shooter game, it's not a game with horror or some big budget art game.

It's a game about how messed up humanity is and can be. It's one about choice.

While this game has many redeeming features, there are some noticable problems. Problem one, the looping of the music doesn't flow smoothy. There are gaps just before it loops which really jolts the atmosphere. Problem two, apart from going to sleep and dying, if you starve your character there is no consequence. Problem three, there are slight bugs relating to the endings and god did I hate the continous 'ending'. You get stuck in the house and can do nothing except play games. While to others this may seem like a fufilling ending, showing the looping nature of human life, to me it felt awkward. I looked around for ages trying to find some hidden thing and found nothing.

I may have complained quite a bit about this game but I honestly recommend it. It's an amazing game that will leave you feeling empty at points and thrilled at others.

reviewText:
This isn't like some triple A. You don't make choices buy clicking a button. You don't make choices by choosing from two. You make choices with your money and your time, similar to Papers Please.

This is a phenomanal game in which you, having been kicked out your apartment with little money to your name, must journey across the country to attend the wedding of your ex and win them back. I haven't beaten this game yet, but I'm a chunk of the way through. I think I've pretty much won. I guarantee you I haven't.

The choices you make define who you are. I killed a woman, or put her life in serious risk, for $30 towards my salvation. I fell on and killed a man attempting to destroy a city, all for money I never got. I made children watch their father die for a car. I made some horrible choices. Consequnce is real in this game. The choices I made I never believed would result in death. People are dead because I need to go across the country. When you are desperate, every choice you make seems to harm those around you.

Always Sometimse Monsters is scary. It's not a horror game, but its scary because it explorers the consequnces of our actions. My character may starve because I payed my rent, for an apartment I never even needed. I just felt it was the right choice.

The choices we make define who we are. In Always Sometimes Monsters, it's a journey of self discovery.

reviewText:
You have only 1 mission: Make choices.But do we always choose what is right, or are we always sometimes monsters?

Instead of a hero saving the world, you are a regular down-and-out writer living in a cruel society. A year ago, you signed a deal with a publisher and foresaw a bright future with your significant other. What followed was a chain of events that would set your life downhill for the next year.

Now, you are alone. Your career is on the verge of collapse. Your wallet is empty, and so is your stomach. Your ex is getting married in a city across the country, and you are invited. You are homeless because you could not pay the rent.

Would you steal and lie, or work honestly?
Would you do everything you can to win back your love, or learn to let go?
Would you attend the wedding to voice your objection, or give your regards?
Would you leave your friend to die, or sacrifice yourself for their good?

These are some of the questions you will find in this game. The game is not a typical RPG game. You don't have weapons, you don't kill people unless you choose to.

In life, sometimes there is good choice and bad choice. But sometimes, there is no choice at all. What would you do? How far are you willing to go when your life, happiness or future is at stake?

This game has, in my opinion, one of the best stories I have ever seen. It makes you think about choices and consequences. If you are not into narrative games, this game may not appeal to you.

Flawed in parts, but perhaps understandably given the amazing scope of this unique game, if you can look past its presentation you will have a memorable time with it

reviewText:
Have you ever promised something to someone and didn't follow thru?

Did you ever miss out on a concert to spend time with your boyfriend/girlfriend/wife/husband?

What were the consequences of your choices? That is what this game is trying to explain that we live far more complex lives than we think and it is changing the way we look at the medium of video games.  Its not about acheviments, high scores or saving the world.  This games makes the player realize that the choices we make have an impact on the people and world around us.  While its not a traditional game it is an experament that video games can be art and delve into the human condition.  If you are going into this game with doubts I'd say play it and it may or may not be for you but for me it made me realize that we can have major impacts on lives by making trivial decsions.  It's def something to think about.

reviewText: A surprisingly long game with a surprisingly simple concept: choice. And damn, are the choices hard. Part of the reason why it's so addicting once you start to play is because of the choices and their consequences and/or benefits. It's also replayable--something that can't be said for most games of this nature. I definitely reccomend this game if you're looking for a good story and if you have a clear schedule. It's likely you'll sink a few hours into this without even realizing!

reviewText: My girl left me, my publisher fired me, I'm broke, AND THE PROM IS TOMORROW!\n\nOn a more serious note, this is a great game that got me geniunely involved with the characters. Most games make you abundently clear that the characters are just that- characters. But in Always Sometimes monsters, I really felt like they were real people, with real consequences for my actions. This isn't a game for everyone, but for someone who likes adventures, a smidge of romance, and grey-and-grey moral choices that could end in disaster or in triumph, this is a shining example of what an RPG should look like. My only qualm was that it wasn't long enough.

reviewText:
I really want to be able to recommend this game....but I can't. Always Sometimes Monsters has a lot of potential but is just lacking overall. The pace is juuuuust slow enough to be considered a hindrance, and while it is definitely a game that makes you think about the morality of your choices, there's a final step it isn't taking. In the end nothing really ends up having consequence. I got it half off so it's not like I'm upset about buying it, and honestly I think I would have been okay paying $10 even because it does have a lot of good qualities. But overall it sits pretty neutral with me so if I had to say yes or no, I'd say no- the bottom line is you're not missing a life changing experience by NOT playing this.

I'm not completely done and I do plan to finish and maybe play again to see if much changes depending on your choices, but I'm far enough along where I'm pretty sure my feelings won't change by the end. Again, the game isn't awful by any means, but I can't exactly justify raving over it.

One thing that did really frustrate me though: the game quits when you try to take a screenshot! Another review had stated this but stupid me tried to do it anyway, and of course I was right in the middle of something...waaaay annoying. I wonder if this is something with games made in RPG Maker? because To The Moon does the same thing...except instead of quitting the game pauses, which I think is a thing Always Sometimes Monsters could use to incorporate to save some frustration.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed Always Sometimes Monsters a lot up until around the 80% mark; the music, dialog and sense of exploration were all very well done. The choices are kind of a mixed bag, as much as I liked the different scenarios and branching I found that too many of them were just black and white moral choice.  In fact I can’t recall a single one where I had to sit there and think “Wow, what should I do?”; it was always “Yeah that’s the good karma, that’s the bad”.  Still I don’t view that as a true negative as the game is a blast even with binary moral choices.

The main issues I had with the game are that I didn’t care at for the characters and the conflict that the story revolves around feels hollow.  For the characters; all of the key ones are kept in the background too much so you really don’t gain a connection to them.  Rather the game just tells you have a connection and leaves it at that.  The PC isn’t much better; I had hoped to play him more like myself but sadly you can select the action and never the tone.  Even playing the game as unselfishly as possible you're still going to come off as a jerk.

I’m not going to spoil anything about the conflict but odds are you’ll see it coming by the second city (and see the ending coming even before that).

Overall I had a great time playing the game up until the big reveal and from there I had to force myself to finish it.  If you’re the type of person who can play to a certain point and stop (and enjoy interactive stories) or ignore a percentage of a game then it's defineitly worth  a look.  But if you push through until the end there’s a chance you’ll came away from it unsatisfied. 6/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This game. This is my first review of any of the 43 games in my library that I thought worth the review, it's that good. My only concerns were a couple very knitpickey things: automatic choice boxes when I'm flipping through text could cause me to choose things I didn't want like not writing in the journal, food was always my biggest concern and a lack there of caused me to die in my sleep(not to mention the prices and scarcity of money), those were my only concerns with the gameplay. Now the story. Holy Lord. I'm reminded of a tumblr post mentioning a game idea where the player had to make a series of choices thinking they were the hero, but as the game progresses the choices become harder and harder and the player realizes they were the bad guy all along. I set off to do the big hero choices and be the most nobel of men...nope. I started off pretty well making somewhat minor mistakes, then bigger ones. The biggest fault I can place is on no one but myself, because these were choices I thought I would make. This is a phenominal game that anyone with a taste for RPG's will love. A word to the wise though, be careful, stick to your own path, and above all, don't relate this to yourself and those around you in case you stray from your path. It WILL mess you up.

reviewText:
Ok so you want wondering if you should buy this game and you are looking in the steam user reviews and you happend to see my review and you see what i have to say. well what I have to say is this. This game is a great game for people who like a thick plot and choices that can change everything you know that is near and dear to your heart. if you don't...then just don't get this game. here are the pros to the game. The graphics are phenomenal the player and npc sprites are nice. the world is good and the top down perspective just makes it all work really well together. The dialog is really nice it makes you feel as if you are the character and you are talking to the npc.

Now the game play is pretty good. it plays like the over world in the old pokemon gameboy games were the character is in a overworld and he can go into biulding and interact witht he nc int he towns, or in this case a city.

Now come the cons. when you start the game it doesn't really tell you when you are selecting your character it just puts you in a room and you have to figure out what you have to do. for some people they will get this rigth away and have no problems, but for other they might be wondering what is going on. this is only minor thow because it will let you change your character if you are unplease by who you selected.

Sometime the game will delete you saved data and you will have to either start from a auto save or start from scratch. I only see this as a minor problem and will really only affect you if you are far in the game or just don't like doing thing more than once.

overall this is a good game and I would recommend this game to anyone who likes game where you are the one who is making the big decisions and doesn't mide reading for about five minutes. (that the longes I have read for one dialog)

reviewText:
First, and most importantly, you should not go into this with any preconcieved notions about anything. Don't assume this game is going to be one way or another. Play it, all the way through the roughly 6 hour story, and take it for what it is: a personal game about choice.

Now, then. Always Sometimes Monsters is a story heavy RPG-esque game. It contains themes that are big in modern society, and manages to still handle them gracefully. Though I have played one run(and plan to do a few more), I feel what I have seen and played is a solid feel for what the game has to offer. This game is, in the weirdest sense, trying nbot to be a game, but more a narrative that takes place within the constraints of a video game. This litle tidbit is explored in a neat post-credits cutscene. I thoroughly enjoyed the 8 hours I've played so far, and I find that this was definitely a good investment. However, this is a review, so it should be lookedat from an objective standpoint. Please keep in mind, I have only done one full playthrough, so I can only vouch for certain aspects.

Characters: The characters are, to be frank, very fun. They have enjoyable lines which can make you laugh, cry, and possibly be very angry. I played as a standard white-bread hero, chasing a pretty white girl, so the story didn't incorporate race, sexuality, or gender into it, because it was a fairly standard setup in a video game. My character was, while a bit whiny, quite likeable. I wonder how much the actual lines spoken by your character change from person to person. The characters are flawed, but they don't have a hell of a lot of depth to them. You can really only take what you see on the surface, because we so rarely se the inner thoughts and emotions of these people. Other than that, I found the characters well-made, if a bit shallow.

Gameplay: You're going to pressing the spacebar a lot in this game. Gameplay usually stays on the standard path of learning about people, picking dialogue options, and sifting through menus. However, occasionally, the game deviates and has little set minigames(although games could hardly be used to describe them. They serve as very rudimentary tasks made to earn money to pay for food and bus tickets to other cities. They are, quite possibly, the biggest downfall of this game. They are boring. They're dull, repetitive, and they put you to sleep. They wouldn't be an issue were it not for the fact that they play an essential part in the game. You need money, and to get it, you have to do these jobs. It kills any pacing the story has, and just creates boring, mind-numbing situations for the player. I understand that the guys at Vagabond Dog were probably making them like this to make the point that Yep
recommended: but you've gotta do it." It doesn't make the task any less tedious
hoursPlayed: and the gameplay any less ♥♥♥♥ing monotonous.\n\nThe Story: This is the big part here

Reading the synopsis for Always Sometimes Monsters I thought it was the coolest thing, since I'm a huge fan of simulation and create your own destiny games. Started out pretty good, and went downhill after about 2 hours.
It just didn't deliver as much as I thought it would. It was tedious, unbelievable, and unsatisfying .

reviewText: I heard some great things about the writing, the storyline and how  you choices and actions would affect things.  After four hours, I feel like that time was wasted.  There is a lot of money grinding and action grinding to push the stages along, and the caricatures disguised as people have become insufferable.  Nothing really felt like it was having any effect on the overall story, and realizing that the main plot of this game is really to profess the fact I can't get over my ex after a year and do it them on their wedding day is a trope and a somewhat pathetic story when used in B-List Rom-Com movies.\n\nI really wanted more, and after only reading the reviews at this point, it doesn't sound like I will get anything more out of it.  I finish this glad this was within a HumbleBundle, so I do not feel as though any money was spent on this.

reviewText:
this game is so realistic it's scary.... what supernatural force must the developers have conjured to be able to come up with a game that matches my life that closely...

i started out by accidentally falling into a lesbian relationship and book deal.... then find myself homeless and determined to etch out an honest living and keep to myself. all seems to be going well until i feel feel itchy feet and decide to move again... in my new town i automatically get in the middle of couples fights, end up in the loony bin,  get molested, make trades until a drug dealer breaks me out and afterward get a job loading trucks... granted the job loading trucks paid $150 a day and i only got paid $100 a week for that in real life, and rent in this game is dirt cheap but i wont argue semantics. after that i made friends with my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ boss because i understand those people...

and now i'm kinda scared to play any farther...

i don't know if i should recommend this, i play video games to escape reality and so far this isn't giving me any wiggle room.. but until i end up a sex slave in a seedy motel i guess it still leaves me enough room to dream about a normal life...

reviewText: Pretty much a choose-your-own adventure game except with an incredibly vast number of decisions you can make. The biggest problem, though, is that there is no actual adventure. The first 20 minutes were just mundane, random minutiae. Nothing happened. Also, the dialogue is poorly written, the art is ugly, the engine is painfully bad, and the music is boring and repetitive. I could a very certain type of person who would like this game- someone who spends a lot of time roleplaying on Gaia Online and writes lots of Harry Potter fanfic. That someone is not me.

reviewText:
Always Sometimes Monsters is an RPG developed by Vagabond Dog to simulate survival in modern society whilst driving forward a constant storyline revolving around your chosen character and partner that you choose at the beginning of the game. The responsibility of choosing your own way in life and making important decisions really grabbed my attention when playing through this. It is not your average RPG in which you play a linear story making choices that don't necessarily affect the state of the world and the relationships you have with the people in it, Infact, the choices you make will definately affect the world around you and the way that you are treated by other characters definately towards the end of the game.

The visuals are pretty standard for an RPG of this type, but the attention to detail is definately worth a mention, If you want an interesting visual experience and a great story, this game can definately provide you with both. There are a few graphical problems, particularly with the Hospital Lobby area, the food plates seem to be hovering in mid air and are being eaten by people standing at the ends of the table instead of being sat at it, I don't know if this is a known problem, or if vagabond intend to deal with it, but it isn't an experience ruiner for sure, so don't let it affect your opinion too badly.

The music in this game is incredibly atmospheric, and provides a lot of mood setting for the particular towns and areas. The Laser Destroyer Team did a great job on it and they should be proud of the masterpieces that they produced. One of my favourite tracks is 'Hit the Town', and I suggest you give those a listen if you're into 8-bit themes.

TOTALS:
Graphics: 6/10
Sound: 9/10
Story: 9.5/10 (Absolutely insanely good, but not perfect in every way)
Polised? --Couple of minor scratches 8/10
32.5/40
Overall experience rating: Garunteed memorable game!

RPG lovers will love such a personal and exciting experience ;3" - Bunnieth
